articles.headline: High Prices for Staple Foods Dip, but Volatile Markets Persist
articles.snippet: The prices of rice, wheat, soybeans and several other foods have come down recently, a development that could ease some of the panic in global food markets.
articles.abstract: The prices of rice, wheat, soybeans and several other foods have come down recently, a development that could ease some of the panic in global food markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  After months of startling increases, the prices of rice, wheat, soybeans and several other foods have come down recently, a development that could ease some of the panic in global food markets.

articles.headline: U.N. Pressures Myanmar to Allow Aid
articles.snippet: Frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded that the nation end barriers to supplies and workers.
articles.abstract: Frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded that the nation end barriers to supplies and workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS  With up to 1.5 million people in Myanmar now believed to be facing the threat of starvation and disease and with relief efforts still largely stymied by the country’s isolationist military rulers, frustrated United Nations officials all but demanded Thursday that the government open its doors to supplies and aid workers.

articles.headline: Air Travelers Need to Pack More Money
articles.snippet: Airlines are passing their financial pain to their passengers in the form of sharply higher airfares and new fees.
articles.abstract: Airlines are passing their financial pain to their passengers in the form of sharply higher airfares and new fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Air travel these days is an adventure with many surprises, some of them unpleasant.

articles.headline: A Little Pity, Please, for Lenders
articles.snippet: A G.M.A.C. subsidiary that was a leader in creative mortgages can’t pay its own debts, so it is demanding a privilege that it won’t grant its borrowers.
articles.abstract: A G.M.A.C. subsidiary that was a leader in creative mortgages can’t pay its own debts, so it is demanding a privilege that it won’t grant its borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors thought it had found a safe and profitable business, far away from the ups and downs of the automobile business that was causing so many headaches. Instead, it found an albatross that is now forcing the company to put up billions of dollars just to stay in business and hope for a turnaround.

articles.headline: Blue-Light Specials at Citigroup as Its New Chief Plans a Revival
articles.snippet: Since becoming Citigroup’s chief executive in December, Vikram S. Pandit has been clearing out the corporate attic of weak businesses and unloading worrisome assets.
articles.abstract: Since becoming Citigroup’s chief executive in December, Vikram S. Pandit has been clearing out the corporate attic of weak businesses and unloading worrisome assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit is doing some serious spring cleaning at Citigroup.

articles.headline: Bad Investments and a $7.8 Billion Loss at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: In the worst three months of the company’s 89-year history, American International Group lost $7.81 billion, primarily from bad investments in complex financial instruments.
articles.abstract: In the worst three months of the company’s 89-year history, American International Group lost $7.81 billion, primarily from bad investments in complex financial instruments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fortunes of American International Group, one of the world’s biggest insurance companies, rise and fall on precise calculations of risk. Last quarter, those calculations went seriously awry.

articles.headline: Pentagon Drops Post in Pakistan for Top General
articles.snippet: Maj. Gen. Jay W. Hood’s assignment was cancelled after the Pakistani media excoriated him for his previous job as commander of Guantánamo Bay.
articles.abstract: Maj. Gen. Jay W. Hood’s assignment was cancelled after the Pakistani media excoriated him for his previous job as commander of Guantánamo Bay.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When the Pentagon announced in March that Maj. Gen. Jay W. Hood would become the senior American officer based in Pakistan, it reflected the military’s aim to put a crisis-tested veteran in a critical job at a pivotal time in the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban in Pakistan’s tribal areas.

articles.headline: Questions of Rent Tactics by Private Equity
articles.snippet: Private firms are buying up rent-regulated buildings and harassing tenants to increase vacancies, advocates say.
articles.abstract: Private firms are buying up rent-regulated buildings and harassing tenants to increase vacancies, advocates say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private investment firms have been amassing what may seem like unusual stakes in New York real estate: they have bought hundreds of apartment buildings with thousands of rent-regulated units across the city that produce decidedly meager returns.

articles.headline: Obama Takes a Victory Lap
articles.snippet: There were talks between party leaders and Senator Barack Obama as he made a public return to the Capitol.
articles.abstract: There were talks between party leaders and Senator Barack Obama as he made a public return to the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama began trying to rally the Democratic Party around him on Thursday and struck a tougher tone against Senator John McCain, saying Mr. McCain was “losing his bearings” in his pursuit of the White House.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn
